cvxRiskOpt package¶

Submodules¶

cvxRiskOpt.cclp_risk_opt module¶

cvxRiskOpt.cclp_risk_opt.cclp_dro_mean_cov(eps, a=None, b=None, xi1_hat=None, xi2_hat=None, gam11=None, gam12=None, gam22=None, assume_sym=False, assume_psd=False, centrally_symmetric=False)[source]¶

Reformulates a DRO CC of the type \(\inf_{\mathbb{P} \in \mathcal{P}} \mathbb{P}(a^T \xi_1 + b + \xi_2 \leq 0) \geq 1-\epsilon\) where \(\mathcal{P}\) is a moment-based ambiguity set.

This function reformulates a distributionally robust optimization (DRO) chance constraint (CC) where the distribution is unknown but belongs to a moment based ambiguity set with known mean and covariance:

\[\begin{split}\begin{align*} \xi &= [\xi_1^T \xi_2]^T \\ \text{Expect}(\xi) &= [\hat{\xi_1}^T \hat{\xi_2}]^T \\ \text{Cov}(\xi) &= \begin{bmatrix} \text{gam11} & \text{gam12} \\ \text{gam12}^T & \text{gam22} \end{bmatrix} \end{align*}\end{split}\]
Parameters:

  • eps (float) – The epsilon value in the chance constraint.

  • a (array_like, optional) – The coefficient vector a in the chance constraint.

  • b (float, optional) – The constant term b in the chance constraint.

  • xi1_hat (array_like, optional) – The expected value of xi1.

  • xi2_hat (array_like, optional) – The expected value of xi2.

  • gam11 (array_like, optional) – The covariance matrix of xi1.

  • gam12 (array_like, optional) – The cross-covariance matrix between xi1 and xi2.

  • gam22 (array_like, optional) – The covariance matrix of xi2.

  • assume_sym (bool, optional) – Whether to assume the covariance matrix is symmetric.

  • assume_psd (bool, optional) – Whether to assume the covariance matrix is positive semi-definite.

  • centrally_symmetric (bool, optional) – Flag if distribution is centrally symmetric (Def 3.1).

Returns:

The reformulated chance constraint.

Return type:

cvxpy.Constraint or cvxpy.Expression

cvxRiskOpt.cclp_risk_opt.cclp_gauss(eps, a=None, b=None, xi1_hat=None, xi2_hat=None, gam11=None, gam12=None, gam22=None, assume_sym=False, assume_psd=False)[source]¶

Reformulates a CC of the type \(\mathbb{P}(a^T \xi_1 + b + \xi_2 \leq 0) \geq 1-\epsilon\) where the distribution is Gaussian.

This function reformulates a chance constraint (CC) where the distribution is known to be a Gaussian distribution with:

\[\begin{split}\begin{align*} \xi &= [\xi_1^T \xi_2]^T \\ \text{Expect}(\xi) &= [\hat{\xi_1}^T \hat{\xi_2}]^T \\ \text{Cov}(\xi) &= \begin{bmatrix} \text{gam11} & \text{gam12} \\ \text{gam12}^T & \text{gam22} \end{bmatrix} \end{align*}\end{split}\]
Parameters:

  • eps (float) – The epsilon value in the chance constraint.

  • a (array_like, optional) – The coefficient vector a in the chance constraint.

  • b (float, optional) – The constant term b in the chance constraint.

  • xi1_hat (array_like, optional) – The expected value of xi1.

  • xi2_hat (array_like, optional) – The expected value of xi2.

  • gam11 (array_like, optional) – The covariance matrix of xi1.

  • gam12 (array_like, optional) – The cross-covariance matrix between xi1 and xi2.

  • gam22 (array_like, optional) – The covariance matrix of xi2.

  • assume_sym (bool, optional) – Whether to assume the covariance matrix is symmetric.

  • assume_psd (bool, optional) – Whether to assume the covariance matrix is positive semi-definite.

Returns:

The reformulated chance constraint.

Return type:

cvxpy.Constraint or cp.Expression

cvxRiskOpt.mpc_helpers module¶

cvxRiskOpt.mpc_helpers.cp_var_mat_to_list(mat: Variable | Parameter, horizon: int)[source]¶

Converts a 1D or 2D cp.Variable/Parameter matrix to a list of cp.Variable/Parameter vectors.

E.g. (3, 4) matrix where horizon is 4 turns into [(3,), (3,), (3,), (3,)]. (3,) of horizon 1 turns into [(3,)] (4,) where 4 is horizon turns into [(), (), (), ()]

Parameters:

  • mat (cp.Variable | cp.Parameter) – (m, horizon), (horizon, m), (m,), or (horizon,) cp.Variable

  • horizon (int) – horizon (e.g. MPC horizon).

Returns:

cvxRiskOpt.mpc_helpers.expect_cov_x_t(t, A, B, x0_mean: Variable | Parameter | Expression, x0_cov: ndarray, u: list, w_mean: list, w_cov: list)[source]¶

Computes the expected next state E(x_{t}) and its covariance Cov(x_{t}) for a linear system x_{t+1} = Ax_t + Bu_t + w_t. E(x_{t}) = A^{t} x0_mean + sum_{i=0}^{t-1} (A^i B u_{t-1-i} + A^i w_{t-1-i}_mean) Cov(x_{t}) = A^{t} x0_cov A^{t}^T + sum_{i=0}^{t-1} (A^i w_{t-1-i}_cov A^i^T) :param t: current time step for x_t (t >= 1) :param A: dynamics matrix :param B: input matrix :param x0_mean: mean state at t=0 :param x0_cov: covariance of state at t=0 :param u: list of control decision variables :param w_mean: list of noise mean value :param w_cov: list of noise covariance values :return:

cvxRiskOpt.mpc_helpers.lin_mpc_expect_xQx(t: int, horizon: int, A: int | float | ndarray, B: int | float | ndarray, u: list | Variable, Q: int | float | ndarray, x0_mean: Parameter | Variable | Expression, x0_cov: ndarray | None = None, w_mean: list | ndarray | None = None, w_cov: list | ndarray | None = None)[source]¶

Finds the E(x_t^T Q x_t) term.

Finds the E(x_t^T Q x_t) where x_t is a random variable at timestep t in the MPC horizon and the dynamics are: x_{t+1} = Ax_t + Bu_t + w_t.

Parameters:

  • t – current control time step (starting from 0)

  • horizon – MPC horizon length

  • A – dynamics matrix

  • B – input matrix

  • u – list of control decision variables (or cp Variable)

  • Q – state cost matrix x^T Q x

  • x0_mean – mean state at t=0

  • x0_cov – covariance of state at t=0

  • w_mean – list of noise mean value (or single noise mean)

  • w_cov – list of noise covariance values (or single noise covar)

Returns:

cvxRiskOpt.wass_risk_opt_pb module¶

class cvxRiskOpt.wass_risk_opt_pb.WassDRCVaR(num_samples, xi_length, a=None, b=0, a_k_list=None, b_k_list=None, alpha=0.1, support_C=None, support_d=None, used_norm=2, vp_suffix=None)[source]¶

Bases: WassWCEMaxAffine

Provides a high-level implementation of the DR-CVaR function.

sup_{P in mathcal{P}} CVaR^P[a * xi + b] where a, b may contain decision variables

class cvxRiskOpt.wass_risk_opt_pb.WassDRExpectation(num_samples, a, b=0, support_C=None, support_d=None, used_norm=2, vp_suffix=None)[source]¶

Bases: WassWCEMaxAffine

Provides a high-level implementation of the DR Expectation function. sup_{P in mathcal{P}} E^P[a * xi + b] where a, b may contain decision variables

instance_counter = 0¶
class cvxRiskOpt.wass_risk_opt_pb.WassWCEMaxAffine(num_samples, a_k_list, b_k_list=None, support_C=None, support_d=None, used_norm=2, vp_suffix=None)[source]¶

Bases: Problem

Wasserstein Worst Case Expectation with Max of Affine terms.

This class implements a generic solution for Cor 5.1 (i), eq (15a) with affine loss functions: l = max_k {a_k @ xi + b_k} where xi (m x 1): the random variable for which we have samples a_k (m x 1): a vector that is either a constant vector or a scalar times a decision variable (cvxpy affine expression) b_k (1 x 1): a scalar or a 1-dimensional cvxpy affine expression

Note

Currently, this is only implemented for the 1-, 2-, and inf-norm cases.

Parameters:

  • num_samples (int) – The number of samples.

  • a_k_list (list of array_like or cvxpy.AffineExpression) – A list of vectors that are either constant vectors or scalars times a decision variable.

  • b_k_list (list of float or cvxpy.AffineExpression, optional) – A list of scalars or 1-dimensional cvxpy affine expressions.

  • support_C (array_like, optional) – The support matrix C.

  • support_d (array_like, optional) – The support vector d.

  • used_norm (int, optional) – The norm to be used. Default is 2.

  • vp_suffix (str, optional) – The suffix for the variable prefix.

instance_counter = 0¶
